rename.from: memory leak in 1.6.6 when using window.open
rename.to: memory leak in 1.6.7 when using window.open

body:
> This does not happen on electron 1.4.16 but only appears to be a problem in electron 1.6.7.

Are you not able to reproduce it using 1.6.6?

yes also happens in 1.6.6.  believe it has something to do with preload.  removing preload seems to resolve issue but if you look at sample code there is nothing significant in preload.js - only console.log (and debugger)
@lneir could you try 1.6.0 as well? If we can narrow it down to a minor version change than it might be related to the chrome 56 upgrade.
@kevinsawicki  just checked 1.6.0 (on mac) and appears to be fine - no memory growth.

> just checked 1.6.0 (on mac) and appears to be fine - no memory growth.

Do you have time to check other releases and see the earliest release that you can reproduce this? Thanks.
sure, i'l give it a try.

@kevinsawicki did some more testing...  

1.6.0 to 1.6.3 all appear to be fine and eventually give back memory.
1.6.4 to 1.6.7 all never give up memory, continues to grow.

my test was:
-  window.open from main window.
- close the child window.
- repeat first two steps 5 times.

looking at release notes for 1.6.4, wondering if this change to include remote in sandboxed renderer might be cause: https://github.com/electron/electron/pull/8939

> did some more testing...

Thank you so much, really appreciate it ðŸ‘ 

> looking at release notes for 1.6.4, wondering if this change to include remote in sandboxed renderer might be cause: #8939

/cc @tarruda do you think it might be related?

> /cc @tarruda do you think it might be related?

I think it is related, there's probably some code there that prevents a context from being freed when a window is closed. I will try to bisect the issue to confirm if that commit is indeed what caused the bug.

I confirm that  @lneir test case isn't reproducible before @e9b955b9ec353817fafb2db21edec8dd5cb8847e, but I believe the actual bug is caused by the remote module and wasn't noticed until now because each non-sandbox has a dedicated process which is killed when the window is closed.

I will continue investigating.
